questions.question_text_1: Total utility increases at (a / an) ______ rate when marginal utility is decreasing but_______.
question_texts: Total utility increases at (a / an) ______ rate when marginal utility is decreasing but_______.

questions.question_text_1: Statement 1: She derives 100 utility points from eating a slice of bread. Statement 2: She prefers bread over ice cream, and sandwiches over bread.  Which of the two utility theories, viz., the Cardinal Utility Theory (CUT) and the Ordinal Utility Theory (OUT), does each of these statements belong?
question_texts: Statement 1: She derives 100 utility points from eating a slice of bread. Statement 2: She prefers bread over ice cream, and sandwiches over bread.  Which of the two utility theories, viz., the Cardinal Utility Theory (CUT) and the Ordinal Utility Theory (OUT), does each of these statements belong?

questions.question_text_1: “She wanted to buy a printer. However, the ink cartridge was very expensive, and thus she had to drop the idea of getting a printer. She was also hungry and wanted a Dosa. The app on her phone gave her a better price for Idli; so she Idli over Dosa”  The first purchase decision is a classic example of _______ goods and the second is an example of _________ goods.
question_texts: “She wanted to buy a printer. However, the ink cartridge was very expensive, and thus she had to drop the idea of getting a printer. She was also hungry and wanted a Dosa. The app on her phone gave her a better price for Idli; so she Idli over Dosa”  The first purchase decision is a classic example of _______ goods and the second is an example of _________ goods.

questions.question_text_1: Assume person X consumes only 2 goods a and b in a month. Also assume that both goods a and b are normal goods for X. A decrease in the price of good b will lead to X’s consumption of good a to:
question_texts: Assume person X consumes only 2 goods a and b in a month. Also assume that both goods a and b are normal goods for X. A decrease in the price of good b will lead to X’s consumption of good a to:

options.option_text: increase owing to negative income elasticity.

questions.question_text_1: Ram’s toy shop on an e-commerce website was having a dry spell. To boost the sales, he conducted a survey amongst his online friends to understand at what prices they’d buy the toys. He found out that the prices charged were high, and he corrected for this the next day. What kind of pricing strategy is Ram following?
question_texts: Ram’s toy shop on an e-commerce website was having a dry spell. To boost the sales, he conducted a survey amongst his online friends to understand at what prices they’d buy the toys. He found out that the prices charged were high, and he corrected for this the next day. What kind of pricing strategy is Ram following?

questions.question_text_1: See the Demand curves (D1 and D2) in the figure below. Choose all the correct statements pertaining to these curves.
questions.question_text_2: See the Demand curves (D1 and D2) in the figure below. Choose all the correct statements pertaining to these curves.
question_texts: See the Demand curves (D1 and D2) in the figure below. Choose all the correct statements pertaining to these curves.
See the Demand curves (D1 and D2) in the figure below. Choose all the correct statements pertaining to these curves.

options.option_text: An increase in Demand will shift the curve D1 towards D2
A Decrease in Demand will shift the curve D1 towards D2
A Decrease in Demand will shift the curve D2 towards D1
An increase in Demand will not shift the curve D1 towards D2
A Decrease in Demand will not shift the curve D1 towards D2
A Decrease in Demand will not shift the curve D2 towards D1

questions.question_text_1: Consider this hypothetical example: Coca-Cola decreased the price of 300 ml Diet Coke can from INR 40 per can to INR 38. This resulted in consumers buying 7000 cans a week. Before the price drop, consumers bought only 5000 cans a week. In the same week, Pepsi reduced the price of its Black cans from INR 38 to INR 36, which increased the sales of Pepsi Black by a whopping 25%! To add to all the complexity, in the same week, the price of petrol increased by 3%, and that of diesel by 2.5%, resulting in a net decrease in fuel usage by 0.02%. Given all this data, calculate the price elasticity of demand of Pepsi Black (round the answer to 2 decimal places).
question_texts: Consider this hypothetical example: Coca-Cola decreased the price of 300 ml Diet Coke can from INR 40 per can to INR 38. This resulted in consumers buying 7000 cans a week. Before the price drop, consumers bought only 5000 cans a week. In the same week, Pepsi reduced the price of its Black cans from INR 38 to INR 36, which increased the sales of Pepsi Black by a whopping 25%! To add to all the complexity, in the same week, the price of petrol increased by 3%, and that of diesel by 2.5%, resulting in a net decrease in fuel usage by 0.02%. Given all this data, calculate the price elasticity of demand of Pepsi Black (round the answer to 2 decimal places).

questions.question_text_1: A firm has total assets worth INR 55000000/- of which 10000000/- is illiquid. Its total current liabilities sum up to INR 20000000/-.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: A firm has INR 600000/- as accounts receivable (debtors), while its annual sales turnover is INR 6500000/-. Calculate the firm’s debtor days (round the answer to 2 decimal places).
question_texts: A firm has INR 600000/- as accounts receivable (debtors), while its annual sales turnover is INR 6500000/-. Calculate the firm’s debtor days (round the answer to 2 decimal places).
